They value work/life balance, give 3-month parental leave, are more than fair with flex time, offer extensive professional development opportunities, and are a supportive community in and out of the office. I cannot recommend working here enough, and UGA pays Graduate Assistants a stipend higher than many other institutions I had assistantship offers from.
cons: Because the office is incredible and people love working here, the majority of employees stay for lengthy periods of time and it can be difficult to move up past the Career Consultant position.

job_title: Assistant Director of Career Services in Athens, GA
pros: The UGA Career Center is the best workplace I have been employed in. The leadership cultivates a team-oriented atmosphere known for hardworking staff that enjoy their work and that enjoy working with each other. There are opportunities for professional development, a supportive atmosphere for working parents, and a welcoming place to start a career. I highly recommend this office as a destination for higher education, student services, and career development oriented individuals
cons: Though the UGA Career Center itself is excellent, it is not immune to the politics of state education. The university is part of the University System of Georgia (USG) which has made it difficult for individual departments to make decisions to make workplaces flexibly. There is a strong political pressure from the state to ignore Covid-19 precautions and prevent remote work. This has been frustrating and it is certainly something to be aware of if you are seeking a role with any Georgia higher education institution in the current climate (2021).

pros: Somewhat safe job in that there are rarely any layoffs and it is very difficult for managers to fire employees without a long process and the right of appeal
cons:
Upper management in staff positions largely consists of people who have zero business experience or even nonprofit experience. Directors at unit level often make 100% more than the next direct report. 

Management in general are overpaid and under-credentialed while staff wages are low--people with Master's degrees earn in the $20s and pay the same amount for their benefits as a Professor or Administrator who makes $200k.

There is this huge gulf between staff executive pay and their reports; whereas 15-20% would be normal, staff managers--many of whom were recruited from outside the State of Georgia--are making $140k while their next report might make $70k--and their report in turn will make $40k.

Stifling, depressing work environment where people talk about their jobs like a prison sentence. Athens is more expensive every year, but "merit raises" are between 0-2%. The only way to get a raise is to change jobs or get an outside offer.

Salaries do not compare well with other universities. Many people have quit in the past year for remote work and are getting paid 50-100% more.

Executive-level managers are allowed to behave like dictators and to make misguided decisions using taxpayer money with little to no oversight and seemingly no analysis of the manager's credentials. Mission creep is an understatement at UGA.

Employees are told they have to cover vacant positions with no supplemental pay while Directors have huge pots of money to play with, often at the expense of the labor force which is working 2-3 jobs apiece due to the high turnover at the university.

Staff are not being treated well at all and no one cares.

Basically, no HR department to look into management practices. Unit-level HR representatives do not interfere because they report to the power structure responsible for bad decisions and labor violations. The only protection workers have is EOO.

pros: Many fantastic and quality people that make it almost worthwhile. Athens is a beautiful town and UGA has a beautiful and historic campus.
cons: Heavily politically correct. Over four years of full-time employment, I have found that administration is outdated when it comes to what a major university should be. I have worked at three other major universities prior to my time here and UGA is behind the curve both technologically and from a financial perspective. Salaries are extremely lacking but the university refuses to change because people want to be able to say they work for UGA. There is a strong presence of discontent across many areas of employees with the university. My experience cannot be applied to the university as a whole because I know there are some great professionals that work here. However, within student affairs and my department specifically, there is a system of rewarding people who are willing to go-with-the-flow. Hard working people are often taken advantage of by over-delegation and if they are willing to express concerns, they are seen as troublemakers and punished in subtle and not-so-subtle ways. I have seen it happen to many of my co-workers over the years and many of them have left disgruntled. It is unfortunate but all of us have lost faith that the right thing will will happen anymore. I hope that things can change for the sake of the students and the hard-working professionals. They all deserve better.

review_title: Great job, not a lot of growth
pros: Great life/work balance and co-workers can become good friends because turnover is not high in most departments.  I had a clerical position and loved the people I supported.  Academia attracts a smart staff but there can be neurosis, especially if you're supporting professors.  There is not a lot of stress if you're good at your job and you thrive in the routine.  Upper management will support you so long as you do as you're told and do it well.  Really enjoyed government holidays.
cons: UGA is a great bureaucracy, so once you get used to your duties it can get boring.  There isn't a lot of growth within departments because most of the upper management has been there forever and plans to stay even longer (I had to switch to a different department to get a higher-level position).  Talent can go untapped because there's only an incentive to do the job you've been given -- suggesting new things or a new project or a new idea about how something can be done is often met with blank stares.  Most people don't want to do extra work or learn something new even if it means they can be a part of something different/cool.

job_title: Student Affairs Professional in Athens, GA
pros:
The dedicated STAFF, who work hard to keep the University running smoothly.  
The students.  Without them there would be no University. 
The Training and Development courses offered.
cons: No salary increases for staff in the last 5 years. This has made it necessary for many staff members to switch departments in order to try and reclassify themselves to make a decent living.  The problem: departments can have heavy turn over, dedication to one's job is greatly diminished, work load increases for staff who are left in department and they are NEVER compensated for the increase in duties.  The other issue is the staff who never truly grasp the position they took before leaving to another job.  This leaves the position in a mess for the next person hired.  Also, the university used to provide much better health coverage.  Now, the prices keep increasing as the salaries remain the same.  And, having to pay $450.00 per year for parking to work at ones job is wrong.

review_title: Great job for a full-time student!
pros: Tuition is practically free (as part of your pay, you only have to pay about $25 per semester on tuition plus student fees, which equal about 1200... but tuition is basically FREE!), plus you get a very decent pay per hour.  I was only required to work about 15hours/week and was paid about 1300 a month, which means I was making between $21-22/hour... plus! you can access the school's benefits program which is set at a decent price as well.
cons: If you are in an administrative role, as I was, there is not much room for skill/professional growth.  You are essentially happy for the job solely for the pay and free tuition.

review_title: Great Benefits, Pay Could Be Better
pros: Great atmosphere, great benefits. Obviously the work environment depends on what group you're in, but I've always had great coworkers with supportive and flexible managers. I'm a woman in IT but I've never felt marginalized here. Can't say that about some of my previous employers.
cons:
Pay is nowhere near competitive with the private sector. The benefits make up for that somewhat, but that gap seems to be widening. 

There's no official maternity leave. If you've been working here for several years, you can probably bank enough sick leave to take a month or two because it rolls over year to year (which, by the way, is awesome), but what happens when your baby gets sick after you've used all that up for maternity?

Parking should be included with employment - some lots have very expensive parking passes.

review_title: Decent work at a great university, horrible prospects for future advancement.
pros:
Decent work, decent pay (for the public sector), decent benefits.

Working with students is usually a plus.

Instructors and staff understand your role (most of the time).
cons:
At the end of the day you're dealing with management that often negotiates and consolidates its own power through mini-cliques, politics, and the status quo, but on the other hand most end-users understand the limits of your job and won't tear your head off should you need more time to fix something.  

Budgets getting cut left and right.

Frequent shorting of support staff - often you end up on your own.

review_title: UGA is a great place to work!
job_title: Public Relations Coordinator in Athens, GA
pros: Lots of resources (both in budget and in opportunities). Strong benefits for employees. Fair compensation compared to low-ball salaries at many other higher ed institutions. When I interviewed, they paid for my lodging on campus and for all my travel expenses. Lots of opportunities to be promoted. Raises offered yearly most of the time (based on employee performance). Faculty/staff memberships available at the on-campus Ramsey Center for working out and taking fitness classes. Discounts at the bookstore and opportunity to get discounted season tickets to a variety of sports. Athens is a wonderful place to live, with great restaurants, parks, and the State Botanical Gardens. Lots of fun things to do here.
cons: The university is very large, so it takes a while to get the hang of things. Employees pay anywhere from $10 to $40 per month for parking, and your parking pass is only for your one assigned lot. However, you have the option to use a departmental vehicle or a departmental parking pass if you are going to a different area of campus for work business.

job_title: Business Manager II in Athens, GA
pros:
Great benefits, especially health insurance and vacation/holidays; start warning 3 weeks of vacation plus paid holidays which typically includes the week off between Christmas and New Years.

Most jobs are 8-5 which is helpful for people with children and commitments outside work.

TAP (Tuition Assistance Program) allows you to earn a non-professional degree without having to pay tuition, including a Masters or PhD. Downside is you can only take 2 classes at a time so it will take longer to complete.
cons:
Salaries for staff below industry standard. People work here for the benefits and job security, not the pay.

Plus raises are controlled by the state and Board of Regents and thus often very small and usually negated by insurance premium increases.

Currently the only way staff can get a decent raise is to constantly look for promotions and change jobs.  So if you enjoy your job and coworkers you have to decide whether to take the risk of potentially sacrificing that for a bigger paycheck.

pros:
The people are generally friendly, the cost of living in Athens is low, and there's an interesting dynamic between UGA and the city of Athens that is rather unique.

The University still has some clout and prestige left and there's a way to get tuition waved for full time employees who are interested in taking classes part time.
cons: Workplace policies are enforced inconsistently. The campus is becoming a more violent area as the University contributes to the poverty rate and stands as one of the places in Athens where most self-defense means are illegal. Pay for professors, researchers, and graduate students are among the lowest for Tier 1 Universities in the South-East, let alone the nation. The IRB has become needlessly restrictive since the construction of the medical school. Access to academic facilities are shut down on game days unless you're caring for research animals.

review_title: Not the prestigous institution I thought it would be
pros: There are some staff that care and want to make things better for the student and staff experience. I can leave at 5pm and not have to worry much about work till the next day. Receiving professional development funds.
cons: Lack of collaboration between units. Lack of innovation and desire to innovate from some staff and leadership. Some leadership have been in positions too long and have become out of touch with current practices and trends and show no desire to get back in touch. Lack of care and compassion in supervision and management by some leadership. Lack of vision. Some leadership consistently viewing staff as incompetent and lazy and only take a condescending tone when discussing with staff their performance concerns rather than show any genuine interest in helping them improve. Staff recognition and appreciation are not built into the culture. Low pay for staff below Associate Director roles.  University struggles with discussing and making progress on diversity and social justice issues.

review_title: Working for UGA is great, especially if you are a student.
job_title: Climbing Wall Supervisor in Athens, GA
pros: There are many reasons to work for UGA. One of those is that you work where you attend school. So if you get out of class, you can go straight to work or vice versa. You also get to see the university from a different angle than others. You get to know the people in charge and know the in' sand out's if everything a lot better. One last pro is if you are a student working on campus, the employers are very understanding about scheduling issues due to classes and tests.
cons: One of the challenges is transportation. To park anywhere on campus, you have to have a parking pass, which is very expensive. Having one makes life easier, but be prepared to fork out a bunch of money. Another con is that almost all of the student jobs only pay minimum wage, or at best $7.50.

pros: UGA has a small family feel to a ver large institution that makes it an easy place to work.  You are given access to as much education opportunity as you want and my supervisor was very willing to allow employees to pursue educational goals while on staff.
cons: The major con was the salary structure.  A person was not allowed to increase their salary based on their worth.  it was always based on time servered and your seniority.  so no matter the job you did or the achievement you accomplished, you would always be in the same income bracket.  Below the person above you and above the one below with no opportunity to advance out of that.  Was told that a raise for me meant a raise for everyone else too.

pros:
Some of the obvious benefits to working for the university is that your managers must understand your position as a student first. You're able to prioritize your time and work with bosses since classes and exams are far more important. Students are hired on for mainly supporting roles so you don't necessarily have to worry about running the show while you're there.

I was in a position where I was able to contribute more heavily towards the operations of the university. The experiences made me feel better prepared because I had become accustomed to solving problems that professors or our guests encountered and was a great stepping stone towards real service-line work.
cons: Depending on the departments that you work with or just plainly the people that you call co-workers, your mileage may vary. Some students pick up these jobs just because they're jobs and are not necessarily interested in doing things outside their job descriptions. Not necessarily a complete issue, but it does contribute to a slower & less interested culture at times.

review_title: Staff at UGA are definitely not the priority...
pros: They're fairly flexible with scheduling if you find the right position. Working with students can be very rewarding. Benefits are fairly good. Go with the ORP plan over TRS. You're immediately vested and they typically match a good amount.
cons: Faculty members can be either a blessing or a curse, more often than not the latter. If you're staff, there's no way to move up unless you get more education. Raises are almost impossible to come by and pay is already terrible. Again, if you have the right faculty your job can be great, but more often than not they're a huge pain in the rear.

review_title: "Good place to work, but lower pay than other universities"
pros: Like most places, the quality of your work environment will depend upon what department and/or team you work for, but I found it a good experience overall.  The need for work/life balance was respected by most managers.  It is a relatively large school, and after six months you can apply for other jobs and transfer, which is the best way to advance.  Also, provided your manager allows flexibility with your hours, you can use tuition assistance to take classes for free.
cons: The pay is low for similar jobs elsewhere.  There are often not very good paths for advancement within one department, and transfer may be necessary (but not always possible) to raise salary beyond very small annual raises.  There are frequent complaints about communication from the top down.

review_title: UGA Food Services is a fun place to work if you're okay with not making much
job_title: Student Culinary Team in Athens, GA
pros: Fun environment, generally nice coworkers, generally nice managers, you get to experience a lot of different stations as a student worker, gain specific skills as a student culinary, easy to get hired, difficult to get fired
cons: Low pay, strict hours caps, meaningless write up policy, as a student worker, it can sometimes feel like you're a piece of meat, so many employees it can be easy to get lost in the shuffle, student employee's don't get the chance to perfect many skills because they're always changing stations, bit of an unspoken social hierarchy

job_title: Doctoral Student/Research Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: Great education and reputation ! The staff and admistration are very organized and respond to issues like scheduling or finances very quickly.
cons: Professors can be either really informative or apathetic.  Because professors are divided in their interest of teaching, research and grant writing it is important to do as much research as you can to make sure you get the best instructor  (or advisor if you are considering the masters or phd program). I've had teachers who were excellent research professors, but not the best teachers. Therefore it is important to develop effective independent stidy skills. Keep this in mind if you plan to go to a research focused institution.

review_title: Good postdoctoral institution in general - give careful attention to your advisor
pros:
The University of Georgia  provides good matching retirement benefits to employees. And retirement matching is quite generous. The facilities are well-kept, well-staffed, and the grounds are beautiful. Add to that fantastic football and the workplace is generally good.

Recently, the university is making an effort to incorporate postdoctoral researchers in university policies.

Retirement plans here are very helpful. Because postdoctoral researchers find themselves moving with relative high frequency, the University of Georgia has a plan (the Optional Retirement Plan) in place whereby they are immediately vested in retirement contributions.

Health plans are affordable for individuals and are simple to use.
cons: Downsides of work at UGA as a postdoc are largely dependent on your immediate supervisor.

review_title: Good place to be if you work in the right fields, but if you don't . . .
pros: Pleasant city, nice weather.  Athens is a nice town to live in, but  . . .
cons: The university has a very narrow range of fields in the humanities and social sciences in which it has any actual interest.  Essentially, the further you move from the US South, the less interest and support the institution will have for you and your work.  If you study and teach an area outside the US, be prepared for total indifference to everything you produce.

review_title: Both challenging and rewarding, UGA offers an engaging career and top-talent coworkers
pros: Top-notch coworkers, ability to expand one's professional growth, with an emphasis on innovation and resourcefulness defined my working experience for the University of Georgia.  The IT department for which I worked encouraged innovative thinking and creativity within my role to meet departmental requirements at minimal cost.  My role while at the University of Georgia definitely was an asset in preparing me for my following IT consulting job.  Additionally, programs like the Tuition Assistance Program (TAP) make working at UGA quite appealing
cons: As with any publicly-funded institution, salary and growth opportunities are limited relative to equivalent private-sector jobs.  Some faculty and staff that my department serviced espoused characteristics only academia and tenure can tolerate.

review_title: It does what it's supposed to do.
pros: It's easy to get hired as long as you can pass a background check; heavy turnover means lots of job openings; dress code varies by department but mine was almost too casual; it's very hard to get fired. But if you need a job to pay the rent or buff a resume, or because your passion really is college administration, it's great. Health benefits are great if you can afford them and leave time is extremely generous.
cons: Our departmental IT was awful and overbearing; if you're not executive or a professor you WILL be EXTREMELY underpaid; a ton of mandatory or 'optional' paycheck deductions; parking is ridiculous; little training; there is a major cultural hierarchy between professors, executives, white collars, and blue collars.

pros: UGA offers a large and diverse campus, but once you've found your niche, it's a small and cozy world! What's more is that it's a quality education (with numerous lab and study abroad opportunities), and there's always some event going on, so you're never bored. There's also a tons of jobs available to students on campus (I've personally worked two).
cons: Some people I know can feel overwhelmed by the magnitude of the place, but that quickly gets taken care of once they get to know the place and participate in the community. It also helps to move off-campus if you can afford it.

job_title: Office Assistant/Mail Clerk for UGA Housing in Athens, GA
pros: They are very flexible with your hours and will work around your class schedule. The job was very easy and left a lot of time for studying, getting school work done, or just hanging out with your awesome coworkers.
cons: There was often a lack of communication between management and student workers which sometimes created confusion. The pay is barely above minimum wage, but that is to be expected of an on-campus job since they are in such high demand. Speaking of which, when trying to get the job it definitely helps to know someone. If you don't know someone who already works there or who has worked there, I would recommend stopping by to introduce yourself in person.

pros: Great people all around who look out for you. Fun workplace to be with entertaining coworkers.
cons: There are people who are moving, learning, and growing, then there are people who have peaked. They were promoted to a job above what they are good at, but no one ever gets demoted. Google search the Peter Principle to better understand how the management ends up being a manager who should be a coworker. Definitely a hierarchy structure of business where you have to be careful about which emails you send and who you have to CC on them.

job_title: Research Professional II in Athens, GA
pros: This is a 100% research-funded position so many of the positives come from the group of people I work with and from my PI. I have always had schedule flexibility, opportunities for advancement and professional development, and an easy-going but professional work environment. My boss was wonderful when I had my son and allowed me to arrange a flexible maternity leave. I also had a good environment that supported me as a working, breastfeeding mother. I love Athens and have found a high quality of life for me and my family in this city. Part of that quality of life is because of the work environment I am a part of and that makes up for some of the cons.
cons: The salary is lower than I would be making in the private market or in a bigger city.

pros: To me, the most important aspects of any job are the culture and the people. At UGA Housing, I really enjoyed working with my fellow RAs and my supervisor. My supervisor respected my time and was always clear with what she expected of us.  My peers were friendly, fun, and unique. I enjoyed learning from their different perspectives as we worked together towards common goals.
cons: Top-management is inflexible. Because there is a waitlist of RAs from previous interviews, top-management is quick to let go of RAs when they have summer internships that interfere with the first week of training.

pros: Working in Rec Sports offers me as a student easy work hours and a fairly thought-free job.  I get to work with fellow students and enjoy being around Ramsey for the most part.
cons: The job can sometimes be mundane.  Pay is minimum wage, but this is to be expected for a student job.  Sometimes, inservices and unnecessary staff meetings can be frustrating.  Some of the bureaucracy in the department makes changes difficult.

review_title: Great opportunities, easy to make real changes
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: Great work environment (in grad school). People who are employed to help seem to enjoy their work. Mostly always an open door policy for research labs. I am a graduate student and my experience has been mostly positive. The fact that labs converse with each other and work together really made UGA an easy choice. My interactions with those in managerial positions seem to like their job and that makes my life easier.
cons:
IRB panel can take more time then is useful. Misc fees keep piling up. Campus traffic can be slow, especially around busy bus lanes.

Few cons: It's no reflection of UGA, but rather labs themselves, but some labs could be better at coaching their students (professional development). Otherwise, very few cons

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Athens, GA
pros:
low stress work environment
PTO/Sick Leave accrual rates above previous
Understanding of personal matters
After some time, pays for some classes if accepted into the university
cons:
low pay for desired skills and experience
busy work to get through downtime
wasteful of resources
lagging technologically
not supportive enough of ongoing development/training - all during work hours and subject to approval from departments

review_title: Nice job,decent pay, interesting people. This job is in the perfect location for anyone living in Athens.
pros: Able to eat as much as you want. Not really much pros their is besides a free employee meal. You get a 30 minute break and food that’s it.
cons: The job you are hired for ISN’T your only job. Example: if you are a Line Cook you are also a dish washer. Get ready to WORK if you apply here.

review_title: The job is a good starting point for a new tutor, but is definitely not good on compensation.
pros: respectable title and prestigious job.  I get a lot out of what I do.  I enjoy working athletes because I know that they often have a hard time balancing sports with studying.  There is definitely a lot of statisfaction when you see a students improved test scores etc.
cons: bad pay, very beaurocratic, work often monotonous.  Just like any teaching job, you will learn a lot while you are teaching, but there is a lot of repetition.  Often more time is needed for certain session, while less is needed for others, but it is hard to get around red tape for payment purposes.

review_title: Enjoy the work and location, not as pleased with the pace
job_title: Human Resource Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: Athens has a lot to do. From community involvement to theater/arts to golfing/tennis/swimming to local breweries/wine tasting to hiking/camping/fishing, there is ALWAYS something interesting to do. I think it's particularly great for singles and couples without children. Working for UGA has good benefits as well, such as use of the Ramsey Center (a massive two story gym), a good retirement system (TRS), free $25,000 life insurance,a variety of optional additional insurance plans (like cancer insurance, additional life insurance, AD&D), and there are extra discounts through certain businesses for UGA employees
cons: UGA has not increases in employe's salaries for 5 years and it does not look like that will change anytime soon. However, the price of insurance premiums has gone up a lot.

review_title: Easy job,  overly emotional boss, too much bureaucracy
pros: A very easy and enjoyable job working at the front desk in a residence hall. For the most part, my hall was pretty laid-back. I was able to watch Netflix or do homework when it was slow. Met lots of new people. Opportunities to "move up" into resident assistant, etc.
cons:
I had an extremely emotional boss that overshared. It made the work environment awkward and uncomfortable. 

Employees fired for silly things. Work there long enough, you will hear about and see a lot of people go. Varies hall to hall but not much leniency on certain rules.

pros: Good benefits. Campus atmosphere is very friendly. Relaxed and enjoyable to work there for a while. Great place to work while you look for a better job.
cons: Pay for technicians and others who do the grunt work is shamefully low. Huge pay gap between doctors and “lower” staff. Rampant nepotism and men frequently get more than women. High turnover rate. Lots of politics to get anything accomplished. Administration is treated with much more respect than laborers. Say they can’t give us raises when they get one every year.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: Challenging environment, Interesting Research. One more word
cons: Professors are too worried about journal publications and tenure that there is tremendous pressure to publish often at the expensive of the broader research goal. Idle threats and postponing graduation are two other perks of being given a mentor with no intention of providing mentorship.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: Love Athens (great town with great music and culture). Campus is mostly pretty. Great opportunities as a grad student in the sciences (teaching, research, travel, conferences, etc.). There is a USDA research facility in town, which provides even more research opportunities and collaboration.
cons: Some buildings are pretty run down and/or old (as are their research facilities). Not a fan of the large Greek population/culture on campus and around town.

review_title: Mandatory Fees and Insurance Make Life at UGA Nearly Unlivable
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: Athens is a great town, professors in my department are overall excellent, and I've yet to meet a graduate student in my department I didn't like.
cons:
The mandatory student fees and health insurance premiums for graduate students are incredibly burdensome. Currently, they come to over $3400 a year. The fees are NOT reduced even if you're employed by the university, which admits that the mandatory fees go to partially funding of grad student employees. So, you're paying for your own salary in effect. 

At both of my previous graduate schools (one public, one private), the fees and insurance premiums were reduced to $50 or less per month. Currently, they're costing me $480 a month at UGA. I have constantly considered leaving because the financial stress is so high.

pros: Decent benefits, actually still have a pension plan / 10 years service to be vested. Most Staff is quite personable and a pleasure to work with. Have a plan for working out discipline when an incident occurs, good in theory only.
cons: The governing body " Board of Regents" is not at all in control. The guidelines for discipline are not followed and problems are swept under the carpet here in 2015. Sad state of affairs. If you play the politics and the good old boy game you will do fine. Be a free spirit and speak your mind you will stay in trouble. People are targeted, especially females working in a males world.

pros: Fortunate to be in a department where there is no micromanaging.  Schedule is flexible and co-workers are decent which is a huge plus.
cons: Pay to park, huge divide between staff and faculty (pay), benefits are getting worse, and just recently going from monthly to biweekly in November has caused me to lose 10 days of pay only to regain when I retire or leave UGA and my budget in this transition is overexerted.

pros:
Extremely diverse technical environment
Staff specialized in many areas are easily accessible
Professional development offered for full-time employees
Excellent benefits
cons:
Draconian adherence to a Faculty > Staff hierarchy is understandable at a ranking university, however some departments have a deeply corrupted view of what that actually means.

Student worker positions can be problematic from lack of training, and general job security as some of these positions are quite complex and struggle with high turn-over rates.

Regardless of salary or tenure, parking is a unilateral fee.

pros: Being an RA is great as you are able to meet amazing residents and build strong connections with people who will be future professionals. You can really be their mentor and advocate for them.
cons: The weekly meetings, 1:1 with supervisors, week-long redundant training and bulletin boards can get a little tedious sometimes. the job really is engrained into your college experience and if you wanted that independent, on my own type of college life then this is not the position for you.

review_title: A long waste of time for sub-standard pay.
pros: Departments are encouraged to spend year-end money, and this makes it easier to get training, even expensive training, near the end of each fiscal year. As at most universities, there is plenty of time off and very good benefits. There are excellent on-campus services, including the Pharmacy, the Health Center and Ramses gymnasium. Athens is a beautiful town.
cons: It remains difficult for UGA to lure IT employees on a basis any longer than 3-4 years because of the low pay and relatively small chances for upward mobility.

review_title: Shockingly low pay for lab technicians
pros: Good retirement and vacation/sick leave policies.
cons: The low pay offered to entry level lab techs is unconscionable. Positions requiring a 4 year degree and a familliarity with molecular techniques pay  scarcely more than custodial positions. (Nothing against custodial workers) but  a rule was made that custodians can't make less than 22K and entry level lab techs are offered 23-24K. How does this make sense???  An entry level veterinarian (8 years college/grad school) is offered 37K. Seriously???

pros: On campus jobs work around the schedule of the student and are at a very convenient location. My professor was also very eager to take me under her wing and teach me about the research the lab was doing. She helped me to make meaningful contributions to the research in my years there.
cons: There were really no cons. I love every minute that I go to work and I really love learning and doing experiments. I can also get a great recommendation one day.

job_title: Food Service Worker I in Athens, GA
pros: UGA's auxiliary services, particularly their food service division, is full of ambitious executives that find solutions to a large problem- feeding thousands of university students on-campus while dealing with frequently short staffing.
cons: The management refuses on a lot of occasions to acknowledge the lack of staffing, usually focusing on "bettering" the staff they already have. This means frequently doing overtime and working above normal productivity levels when part of any ground-floor team.

review_title: UGA is a good place to work.
pros: Family friendly, low stress, job security, very good vacation policy, very good health insurance.  If you want an 8 - 5 job in Athens, this is the place to be.  Summers are very nice because the number of students goes down dramatically.  You can also get employee football tickets.
cons: Salaries are far behind what they should be across the board.  Having to pay to park at the place you work at is absurd.

review_title: Graduate school days, some good and some bad
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: I spent almost 8 years here, 6.5 years as a graduate student and 1 year as a postdoc. Athens is a nice town for a lot of Americans; and as an international student, it took me some time to like it. Weather is nice and has four seasons, 1 hour drive to Atlanta, where you could get more your hometown stuff. People are nicer in the south.
cons: Although the scientific environment is very open and welcoming, the pace to get work published is a bit slow here. It really depends on the group you join.

review_title: Good place to work if your a student looking for a good paying, flexible job.
pros: If your in school and looking for a a good paying job, you can't wrong, at least with being a Bus Driver.  I can't speak for other positions' wages.  However, I do know all student jobs on campus are very flexible in regard to hours, which is great for people with class schedules.
cons: Some seem stuck to doing things a certain way, even if there is a more efficient manner to go about something.

pros: The Franklin College of Arts & Sciences Office of Academic Advising is a very pleasant work environment.  The advisors are all well educated and a joy to work with.  The office director is welcome to feedback and cares about the advisors and the students.
cons: The University of Georgia does not provide benefits for same sex or different sex domestic partnerships.  Athens is a competitive work environment, so it is difficult to get a job at UGA.  Pay is low.

review_title: Not what it used to be!
pros: Decent benefits, time off and personal sick days
cons:
UGA used to be an enjoyable place to work.
Lately more work is asked to be done with less employees
Many employees that have been there several years are not as happy as they used to be.

pros:
Beautiful Campus
Great Benefits (Health, Dental, Vacation Pay, etc.)
Employees seem to care and enjoy what they are doing
You get to be part of the Bulldog Nation
Athens is a great college town with a lot of things to do
Georgia Football
cons:
Pay is on the lower end, but it is a government job
Budget cuts mean that everyone has to do more with less
Politics plays a large role in promotions and lateral hires
Dealing with state red tape can be a nightmare
Senior leadership on campus is lacking. It would be nice to see significant turnover in the Administration.

review_title: Dining Services: Good place to start but hard to move up
pros:
Decent start wage for food service
Meal plan reimbursements, free food before or after shift. 
Great atmosphere if you get to know the right people
Modest yearly merit pay increase (up to $0.30)
cons:
Nepotism when it comes to hiring of student management
Inadequate training of student employees, no uniform training protocol
Limited to 20 hours per week during summer
Not everyone is held to the same expectation

job_title: Tutor/Mentor for Student Athletes in Athens, GA
pros: Working at UGA was exciting because they are innovative and had access to the latest technology for teaching.
cons: Did not provide any kind of benefits as I was only part-time, though paid fairly well for part-time employment.  Hard to keep working there when one has finished their degree and needs to move off campus.  Of course, when one completes a degree, they hope to find a full-time job in their field, but not always the case, especially in today's job market.

job_title: Applications Programmer Specialist in Athens, GA
pros: Great environment and people once you get to know them.  Interesting and challenging hodge podge of systems.  Generally a lot of independence in doing your job and you're left alone to do it.
cons: Organizational structure is very rigid.  Little movement between groups. It generally takes many years to be accepted as a member of the 'in group'.  Pay is generally low.  I had 1 promotion and no pay raises over half a decade (mostly due to state legislature and recession).  Technology is slow to change.

pros: UGA Food services was a good place to work, my coworkers for the most part were like family. I invited some of them to my Wedding last summer, if that gives you and Idea of how close we were. The Summit dinning hall was a very high paced kitchen to work in, it was a great experience.
cons: If you came in early or went home late you would get written up, over time was not allowed. I have never worked for a place that got mad at you for showing up 10 mins early to work or even staying late when they were short handed.

review_title: Graduate stipend is suited to the cost of living in Athens, GA and the faculty are high quality
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: There are a number of great professors to work within the Institute for Artificial Intelligence. There are generally projects for which students of all interests can get involved.
cons: Finding a new graduate assistantship can be challenging each semester, though it can be done with some persistence. One must be quick to respond to an available assistantship, though this is not unique to any university.

review_title: Nice place to cruise to retirement, not begin a career
pros: Job flexibility and stability.  Never worried where the next pay check is coming from.  Senior management is not results oriented, so work life balance is not an issue.  Leaving work for personal issues was never a problem
cons: Opportunities are limited and leadership at senior levels is severely lacking.  Never felt like there were opportunities for advancement.  The majority of senior leadership was either a professor, or a career academic manager with little initiative to advance their own career, and definitely no initiative to advance yours.

review_title: Not a challenge or career advancing organization
pros: Good benefits and discounts on various merchandise with fair leave balances given each month.  Also living in a college town offers many cultural opportunities for the arts and collegiate sports.
cons: No raises or performance based salaries, no overtime pay or time off, sliding job descriptions to cover duties you take on without recognition or compensation, and no opportunity for career growth or expansion due to the highly political nature of higher education.

pros: Most people who do the master's or PhD plan on teaching high school or college after graduation so it's a good experience builder to teach here. You also have the chance to work for one of the study abroad programs. Spanish is the largest program and you have more opportunities to teach advanced courses.
cons: It can be demanding at times, taking time away from your own studying and paper writing. Money is not that good so you wanna come into the program with some savings or planning on having a second part time job to complement your income.

review_title: A Corporation with a Football Team Disguised as a University
pros: If you love college football, a great place to work. Excellent vacation and sick leave accruals. Pretty physical location outside.
cons: Micro-mangers everywhere throughout the organization. Corporate behavior rampant. Training done only to cover the university's behind. Best to kiss but hard and ask no questions in order to advance in most units.

review_title: Big University has many opportunities, but should listen better to employees
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Athens, GA
pros:
- Large university which supports many offices which smaller universities combine or simply don't have
- Close community, based on department.
- Loads of research activity
- Interaction between departments is encouraged
cons:
- Libraries close on school breaks
- I constantly feel nickel and dimed
- Required university email has no spam filter and I end up with at least two spam emails daily. The tech guys don't do anything about this.

review_title: I have found UGA to be a supporting and creating learning environment
pros: The faculty and staff are wonderful to work with. The students are varied and interested in furthering their education. Athens is a great place to live and raise a family.
cons: Salary compression has been a major issue, has been declining support from the state. Leadership at the University is good, but state government does not seem to value UGA the way it should.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: Geography Department front office staff are wonderful! Library resources extremely helpful, with ability to access from anywhere, at any time. Campus bus makes it easy to get around on campus or downtown for lunch.
cons: Tuition is only $25 for grad assistant, but fees continue to increase each year and currently around $900 semester. Not all grad assistant get paid the same; when first being accepted to department you might have some ability to negotiate.

review_title: Good student job but should probably just try for an internship if you want to learn actual skills
pros: They work really well with your class schedule and last minute schedule changes and it is a laid back atmosphere
cons: As a student worker they don't give you enough experience actually learning how to complete documents like you would learn from an internship. You spend a lot of time doing nothing when you could be doing homework and you definitely don't get paid very well.

review_title: Great organization as a graduate school employee!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: The school offers less compensation for graduate students who TA and teach than many other schools, but this should be seen in the context of Athens, GA.  Athens is the most inexpensive city in which I've ever lived, and your stipend tends to not only afford you the basic necessities, but you're able to enjoy all that the city has to offer.  Student fees and healthcare (should you choose to enroll) costs will be taken out, but it's become a fairly painless process to work the finances involved in those deductions.  The school offers many resources to graduate students as they do their undergrads, and there are many opportunities for extra funding, as the school is R1.
cons: At times, you're reminded that the undergraduate population is still the first priority of the school, although these instances are few and far between.  Funding could still be a lot better, even though the inexpensiveness of the city affords a nice lifestyle.  TA and teaching responsibilities can be case-by-case, with some granting intelligent students in reasonable numbers with less grading, and some demanding a lot of your time and attention, as well as criticism from your faculty instructor.   It's sort of luck of the draw in many departments, and regardless of which situation you're placed into, you'll be compensated the same as all others.

pros: Athens is the home of the Georgia Botanical Gardens, and has a very low cost of living.  Housing is not difficult to find, and generally landlords appreciate if you are a professional with discounted rental rates.  You are only about 1.5 hours from the Atlanta social life, and the weather and general climate are nice year-round.  Benefits are comparable to some of the better corporate businesses out there.
cons: I personally appreciate an environment where expectations are clearly set, and appropriately evaluated in tangible ways.  This is not that environment.  It seems to me that here whether or not you are promoted is far more guided by who you know that how good you are at your job.  If you don't want to get stuck in a dead end job, this is likely not the best environment for you.  The payscale is deplorable.

review_title: Inadequate Pay, otherwise a very rewarding job
pros: You get to work on a dairy farm and be around/interact with the cows and calves a lot. Management is super friendly and understanding of your class schedule, and very willing to teach you each and every aspect of dairy farm management/operation. If you have never worked on a farm this is a good place to learn basics skills required on a farm based job.
cons: The pay is crap for the amount of skilled work you do. From my understanding, the University doesn't like giving money to the Teaching Dairy so management has to make do with what they have. Seeing as how they only had 100-200 head they don't make much profit to pay employees. Most of the extra money goes to the farm. Most people who stay on for an extended period of time (like I did, I stayed for a year) do so because it is more rewarding of a job than sitting behind a desk on campus answering phones or driving one of the buses. Also if you work there you more than likely will be required to go on a 3 am shift rotation which for some people is hard to balance with school. At the end of the day you get out what you put into everything you do so for some people this is a crap job, but for others, especially those who don't mind hard work and love to be around cows and the farm environment, this is a good fit for you.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Birmingham, AL
pros: Subsidized health benefits. The Department of Romance Languages had a great team to work with, both colleagues and supervisors. Great college town to live in.
cons: The salary is low, but comparable to other assistantships. Parking is expensive. Some classrooms have very good technology and others do not. Sometimes TAs have to go all over campus to teach their classes while carrying heavy books and laptops.

pros:
Great if you are white.
Better if you are male.
Holiday and vacation days are lovely.
UGA students are wonderful. 
Beautiful Campus.
cons:
Underpaid compared to other universities in the USG.
Whatever you get hired at, you will likely stay in that same pay grade for decades.
Micromanagement is rapid, which is NOT something they teach in the Business School. 
The accountability of leadership is lackluster at best.
Employee evaluation tactics are antiquated. 
Colleges and Departments work in silos. 
Managers and leadership promoted into those positions with zero soft skills and no training available to learn them. Ironic, since it is a top University.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Athens, GA
pros: Working here during the pandemic is alright, because I still got to keep my job. I am grateful for that. The benefits are alright and the culture is awesome if you're into football. Staff appreciation day is loads of fun. The students are all fun to interact with and I love learning what cool new stuff the kids are doing with technology and their studies. The students really make this place excell. TAP is amazing. T&D really try to keep you growing professionally, which I appreciate. Staff members can be friendly and welcoming  (there are always bad apples).
cons:
The pay is awful. I cant imagine raising kids on this salary alone like many of my colleagues do. There is your typical office culture, which is neither here nor there. You either love it or you hate it. The software is a little tricky to get used to if you've never been introduced to it before. You have to pay an exorbitant amount to park at your own job, and the benefits can be limiting sometimes. 

 People come to work here for the long haul, but not necessarily for career growth or promotions, but because its stable. Which is a pro in it's own right, I'll admit.  Overall this job is nice but not noteworthy. It's pretty mundane and the pay is lower than other jobs in the area that are classified the same, but at least you get to tell people that you work for UGA (go dawgs!). 

Just be aware when you apply that it's pretty stagnant in terms of growth or advancement. And it takes YEARS to get a decent pay bump or a reclassification..even though we make more than enough to facilitate better pay through the football program alone, not to mention the amount of research that happens here. It's pretty disappointing, but predictable.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: The University of Georgia tends to be well supported by federal funding agencies, so there are more opportunities than at a smaller school.  You don't need to send things off or visit another University to complete your scientific study.
cons: The University of Georgia does not treat graduate students well.  Stipends tend to lag very far behind comparable universities, and health care is very poor.

review_title: Very supportive and positive work environment. I see why people stay until retirement.
pros: Very family oriented, excellent benefits as a State employee, educated co-workers, support for continuing as well as higher education. There are many options within the University System to support changing careers and meeting career goals of employees.
cons: Salaries are usually a bit lower being that you are considered a government employee. Salaries for the same job descriptions/positions are definitely higher in the private sector. You also have to pay to park your car- usually $20- $40/ month depending on how far you want to walk.

pros: The usual advantages of an academic environment are present here and the salaries are competitive with our peer institutions as long as you remain productive and are open to seeking external funding. The town is great and the students are very capable.
cons: The supportive environment that was once present has been dampened by the pressures to fill seats to increase enrollment. Not unique to us, as everyone everywhere is being asked to do more with less. Five years without any prospect of a raise may just break the spirit of the faculty and staff.

review_title: Big university can lead to big problems, but my department was okay
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: There were lots of resources available.  Some connectivity between departments.  Good location, safe.  Plenty of options for entertainment or breaks from work.  Food options great as well.
cons: Have to work around university schedule (like sporting events will kick you out of your assigned parking lot).  Lots of silly bureaucratic hoops to jump through.  Lots of undergrads can be a bit overwhelming as a party school sometimes.

pros:
There are some really hard working, great people here.  
The healthcare and retirement benefits are good.  
The work is interesting and diverse.
The students are great to work with.
cons:
For the most part, staff must change jobs to increase pay and there are very few higher-level positions.  
Training and development offerings are mostly limited to classes relevant to this university only.

job_title: IT Professional Specialist in Athens, GA
pros: Laid back compared to corporate environments. Health insurance is good. No layoffs. Diverse workforce. Mostly 40 hour work week. Ample vacation time, sick time, paid holidays, and paid snow days. Retirement plan. Colleagues are generally friendly, supportive, and cooperative.
cons: No career track to speak of. Raise will be the same whether you go the extra mile or do the bare minimum. Pay not competitive. No corporate perks (food, games, movie outings), not dog-friendly.  Pay to park.

review_title: Georgia Center for Continuing Education & Hotel
job_title: Technology Project Manager in Athens, GA
pros: Great hours. Staff is wonderful. There are many ways to get involved in the development of the hotel. The hotel is on-campus and is right in the heart of Athens.
cons: There are many renovations, making it hard to keep up. During football season, the hotel is super busy, and will overcome you if you don't keep up.

review_title: Quality of leadership, employees and services provided varies tremendously from county to county.
pros: Inspiring mission; many opportunities for training; many forums for sharing knowledge with the community; and collegial rapport and knowledge sharing with employees from other counties.
cons: Quality of leadership, employees and programs varies tremendously from county to county.  Technology is outdated.  Some employees are "missing in action" for years at a time. The matrixed structure of the organization which includes employees funded by UGA, the county, the Board of Education and grants makes it challenging to resolve issues that arise. When leadership is poor and/or an employee exhibits unprofessional and unacceptable behavior, it is almost impossible to resolve these employee issues which may affect Extension's programs and services to the community, as well as overall office morale. For potential employees, check with applicable stakeholders of Extension's programs to see whether they are familiar with programs in the county.  Stakeholders for 4-H (teachers); Agriculture and Natural Resources (farmers, nurseries and gardeners); Family and Consumer Services (Libraries, senior centers or any place where there might be nutrition classes). Check to see whether the county's programs are advertised on its website and through social media channels. If you can't find any online reference to the county Extension office's programs, that's a red flag. If farmers and teachers are not familiar with the Extension office or share negative feedback, that's an important signal. Another con is low pay. Many offices do not provide a standard living wage of $15.00 per hour for salaried positions. Benefits are good.

review_title: A positive place to work and build leadership skills while obtaining one's degree.
pros: The university supports, via its hundreds of service labor employees, the economic structure of Athens. As the university grows, so do the number of people it employs, and as the years have gone by I have personally witnessed the quality in benefits and wages continually improve.
cons: The university system undervalues their service labor employees; a product, I suppose, of enjoying Athens's overpopulated work pool. To value employees, the university should offer subsidized programming, such as specified vocational training and certification, to over-performing employees.

review_title: Absolutely the most incredible work environment I have ever been a part of.
pros: The staff is engaging, dynamic and the leadership is genuinely interested in building the values of their employees as individuals.  All in all a very rewarding division of the University of Georgia.
cons: The challenge comes in the fact that it is a paid-by-the-hour position meaning that it doesn't provide a steady income for a lot of college students.

pros: Ramsey is an incredible place to work as a part-time worker! I have very much so enjoyed working with some of the most dedicated coworkers and supervisors that UGA has to offer! Ramsey provides flexible work hours and holidays off.
cons: There are very few, if any, things that I did not like about working at Ramsey. It sincerely is the best recreational facility in the country and I've loved every minute working there!

pros: Working for UGA while you're an undergraduate is one of if not the best, most flexible jobs you can have while going to school full time.  I worked in the Communications Department for two years, and my hours were whenever I was available, as long as I met my quota.
cons: Since you work for the school, anything you do is not only a reflection of your role as a student, but also your role as an employee.

job_title: IT Professional Associate in Athens, GA
pros: Relaxed work pace, work/life balance leans towards life. Lots of PTO and holidays. Loads of opportunity for professional development, incredible benefits. Most of the people are friendly and easy to work with.
cons: Not much room for upward mobility. When promotions happen, they tend to be due to seniority and not hard work or achievements. This leads to a general attitude of laziness and doing as little as you can get away with.

review_title: Loads of leave/holidays, frozen salaries 6+ years
pros: Center of enlightenment, surrounded by smart young people. Generous with annual leave, holidays, and closed at xmas. Well ranked programs. Created Office of Sustainability and led the nation in study abroad experiences.
cons: Low diversity ratio, frozen salaries for eons, usually have to be an inside hire. Hard to reclassify positions to the work actually being done. Hope scholarship created affluent, entitled, white, metro ATL student population, and perhaps grade inflation.

review_title: Wonderful and Full of Southern Hospitality!
pros: Hours are flexible if you're a student of have a family, great coworkers, everyone is very caring, some of the people higher up really care for their staff and will do anything to ensure that they're comfortable and content at work.
cons: Some of the supervisors and department heads don't really care about the employees at the bottom, but you don't see them enough for it really to affect you.

pros:
The dining hall I worked at, Snelling, had great people.
Very flexible schedule, willing to work around your class schedule and have no problem adjusting things mid-semester if you take on new responsibilities outside of work.
cons: As a baker, I spent the majority of my time doing very similar tasks on a day to day basis, bake a recipe or two, lay some cookies, keep the lines clean, etc. Could get monotonous for some.

pros: The coworkers are generally very nice, and it pays ever so slightly above minimum wage. It is a very good first job.
cons: High turn over rate, and no job satisfaction. I think the turnover rate has to do with the fact that they give 10 cent raises once a year based on job performance, and management specifically gives nobody good enough performance reviews to give anyone a raise.

review_title: University of Georgia - Great Place to Grow and Contribute
pros: Great work / life balance capability; Opportunities to grow, be involved, and progress your career; Melting pot of people, research, education and outreach; Great locations to work, play, socialize, worship.  Main campuses Athens, Griffin, Tifton, Gwinnett, GA
cons: Overall, actual incomes are on average at the lower in of their published pay scales.  Salaries for similar positions probably average about 40% less than the Atlanta, GA market.

pros: calm and inexpensive city,  Safe and beautiful living area. Competitive research groups and good professors that can help you in variety of fields.
cons: Maybe the only thing which could be somehow not pleasant for some groups , is the  size of the city which is a relatively small city. It's not a problem for me but maybe for some others it is !

review_title: It was a fun job but no room for advancement
pros: The benefits are great. Management doesn't keep peeking over your shoulder so there's a lot less stress when it comes to completing assignments. The university is top notch research school so all items needed for the job were provided
cons: There really isn't any room for advancement. The University also has high demands, so completing an assignment on time can be troublesome

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: There is no pressure to perform as opposed to the private sector. The environment is very friendly, people are relaxed, very helpful and easy going. University partially covers the health insurance expenses. University of Georgia is a well established name.
cons: Salaries aren't the best, some academics haven't got pay raise since financial turmoil in 2007-2008 making quite a few prominent figures to leave.

review_title: Overall a good place to learn and develop your skills
pros: The environment is good, it is safe and beautiful. The people are good and has a good academic atmosphere. It also has plenty of resources, including gyms, career center and restaurant. Also the downtown area is near the university, so you can always find same cafe, cinema and banks in the downtown. It is pretty convenient.
cons: The payment for assistant is lower than average. And have to pay the health insurance by yourself. In addition, there are also some other charges before each semester.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: Satisfaction with the job will likely depend on the nature of your department and position.  I did think that the health care benefits were pretty good in terms of value.  There is a clinic on the UGA campus which is better than an urgent care facility, but not quite a hospital.  The fitness center was also pretty nice.
cons: While I was there for three years, my salary never increased.  I believe this was due to the state-wide salary freeze, but still - this was not appreciated.

pros: It provided great opportunities to meet people around the academic community and to make connections. Also, the supervisors were very accommodating with regard to my class schedule.
cons: From the beginning, it was clear that there was going to be little opportunity for advancement (neither promotions nor pay raises...except for when minimum wage was raised).

review_title: A great experience in the short term
pros:
The location is great!! Athens is a pretty interesting and fun town for people in their 20's.

I work with some great and hardworking individuals. People are always willing to help.
cons:
The pay could be better or it would be great to have the chance to add more hours.

A lot of bureacracy so things can progress slowly at times.

review_title: A Secure Job with Good Compensation
job_title: Food Service Manager in Athens, GA
pros: Waived tuition for University System of Georgia schools, reasonable pay, holidays off (incl. Christmas week), free meals
cons: Expectations to devote life to job, salary that doesn't meet level of responsibility, responsibility without authority, micro-managing upper management, lack of trust by upper management, $240-$480 annual fee to park, expectation to work during snow closures, lack of consideration for family / outside of work commitments, requirement to work gamedays

job_title: Engineering Teaching Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: Great professors and students have made it a pleasure to work within the organization. The engineering department is expanding rapidly and bringing in new expert faculty.
cons: The science  and engineering curriculum can be somewhat limited in specific areas. I would like to see the incorporation of more materials science engineering classes and advanced chemistry and physics classes in materials.

pros: people are friendly, weather is nice, and most importantly, there are not as many people as in Atlanta. I can spend more time alone.
cons: My boss is a hard person, but still nice. I really enjoy the life there, and I cannot think of anything else about Cons of UGA. It is a great university.

pros: Fantastic, incredible faculty, staff and students. Fun atmosphere, positive & upbeat coworkers.
cons: Not enough workers & staff, too high volume of business with limited staff available. Lack of ability to schedule student workers effectively due to maximum flexibility in student scheduling. Gaps in scheduling not filled in adequately.

pros: Excellent benefits.  University employment is nice as while it is hectic at times, it's not as frenzied as the corporate world.  Remember you're basically a State of Georgia employee, so after 6 months it takes an act of congress to fire anyone.
cons: Pay is low compared to other Universities and also because UGA is the largest employers in Athens/Clarke County so they can keep the salaries low.  That being said, the costs of good around Athens are all then lower than elsewhere.

pros: Great co-workers, excellent university town atmosphere, decent benefits
cons: will take advantage of lower paid workers... if they give you more work, make sure you get a title change or you will not move up in salary.

pros: It was a great summer job because we started early and ended early. Also, free golf is always a good perk.
cons:
It was difficult to wake up early on some mornings since work started at 6 am every morning. 
Working every other weekend became tough in the summer too because it conflicted which traveling on weekends.

review_title: UGA Hotel -- Incompetent Leadership with Contempt for Employees
pros: Good benefits, week off at Christmas, many nice people trying to run a university property like a business. Hotel is in a beautiful location.
cons: Management has an outdated view of business, customer relationships, employees. Micro-management of employees, no empowerment, horrible morale. Fired whole department to eliminate a minority woman.

pros: Learned a lot about procurement which I felt has given me a good base for future opportunities.  The state's benefits are excellent and the office politics are minimal.  All staff are pleasant and easy to work with and it is always easy to get time off.
cons: Not much chance for advancement - pay is below the industry standard for the job.

pros:
* Flexible schedule
* Great benefits (health, PTO, sick time, paid holidays)
cons:
* Constant changes in HR, finance, etc. systems. Change is a NIGHTMARE here. It is poorly organized, poorly implemented, no structure in place for assisting with the massive transitions they push through
* Hiring is an absolute nightmare (think crucial roles remaining vacant for years because of HR barriers)
* Salaries are low across the board, especially for staff
* Staff are considered unimportant compared to faculty
* No opportunities for growth (promotion, raises, continued education)

job_title: Research and Teaching Assistant in Athens, GA
pros:
World-class research and excellent graduate education, and the center for teaching and learning is an excellent resource for development as a teacher.
University setting provides a rich cultural and intellectual atmosphere.
Faculty and staff are great
cons:
Research assistants are paid substantially more than teaching assistants (~10%). 
Very little flexibility or opportunities for experienced teachers who want more than just teaching a lab.
Compensation has not been keeping track with cost of living increases in Athens, and institutional fees have increased in the same time.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: Athens is a small town, but it's a good place for study and doing research. There are a lot of bars in downtown area, and very safe to walk at night. UGA is famous for its education, law, business, agriculture, animal science. Physics department has a very long history, but the rank is going down slightly due to the lack of experimental research in solid sates physics. EE is very young, but developing very fast.
cons: salary can be increased a little bit.

pros: Very flexible with work hours and working around class schedule. Very mindful of not scheduling work during mid-terms and finals and allowing study time.  Managers are very nice and are great mentors.  Working at UGA  is an overall great experience and a wonderful foundation of practical work experience paired to my degree.
cons: No downside whatsoever to working at UGA as a student worker.  I can't recall any problems or issues with any co-workers, management, etc.  No improvement necessary.

review_title: Great one, I love to work in the University of Georgia.
pros: If you are working at University of Georgia, it means you would enjoy beautiful campus, nice people, nice weather, nice city.
cons: Athens is a college town, small city. For those who have been enjoying big city life, it's probably not a perfect choice.

pros: There was a great deal of flexibility since I was still in school. I had my own desk and enjoyed working with my team. I liked the confidence they had in me! Lastly, I enjoyed that my job was project oriented.
cons: There was a limit on how many hours I could work since I was a student. I would have liked to put in more hours. Sometimes working with an office of all women can be a little difficult sometimes.

review_title: Game Day Ambassador - Great Student Job!
job_title: Game Day Ambassador in Athens, GA
pros: Thriving, guest services environment with an opportunity to hone customer service skills in a positive and welcoming setting. Accommodating schedule for a full-time student.
cons: I didn't experience any negative experiences in my term at GAH. Odds of drunkards on game day is inevitable, but they aren't unpleasant to deal for the most part.

pros: Free meals, flexible schedule, something to put on a resume to showcase hard work and some skills
cons: It's not a glorious job, you'll be cleaning dishes and on your feet a bit. The management is not always great or sympathetic and you can feel as if you aren't appreciated.

pros: Perfect if you're a student.  Complements college life well.  They really work with your schedule and your desired number of hours so you can get what you want out of it.
cons:
Not really repetitive.  Every event is new and different.  Sometimes for the better or worse.  
Also, sometimes having to work weekends and nights are necessary (this includes football games)

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: This is a great place to work, but the pay is not very large.  Fun campus environment with flexible hours for some computer science department teaching assistants.
cons: The pay is stagnant, and the payroll system is a nightmare.  Getting promoted within a department can be quite a bit more difficult without a PhD.

pros:
Good environment good people good town
The facilities of the university is excellent gym library centres activities busses tickets discounts all of this adds up
cons:
Low pay
There is really not much to complain about of you stay away of students partying and hide from traffic during game days and watch out from Florida team fans

pros: Good atmosphere to work and a great experience
cons:
Lack of information about general issues like health insurence I knew about health saving accounts one year after hired. Orientations are advertisements you’ll never get any needed information that would help you. For example, no one would tell you how to enroll in a suitable benifit but they advertise for those of their benefits!
Many workshops are just for advertising as well!

pros: Both of my assistantships (CED and Marketing) were 13 hours/week. Included a stipend and all but $25 and fees of tuition. Fairly chill. Really depends on who you're working for and what you're doing.
cons: 13 hours can be harder to get than you would think! There's plenty to do with an assistantship and 15 credit hours so don't overload yourself.

review_title: Good job to have while in college
pros: Interesting work for an undergrad. I was able to make the lessons what I wanted to and try to cater to students needs.
cons: Not a lot of communication between the professors and the teaching assistants. We frequently did not know what was said in class which made it difficult to teach at times

pros: Paid time off, great location in Athens, Georgia. Eligible to take up to 9 credit hours per term for free if approved by your department.
cons: No incentive, no equity in workload, supervisors may be inept and lack managerial skills, no cohesion, no raises. Almost impossible to get fired - many people have worked in the same position for 15-20 years and are still unable to properly complete their job function.

pros:
I basically make my hours and the work is not difficult
UGA is very willing to help their employees in any way they can
cons:
Parking is still an outrageous price even for employees
I was never trained and expected to know how to do everything
I still lack guidance and have to track down my supervisor to get any

review_title: Collegial space, but needs more resources
pros: Most of the the coworkers are extremely collegial, Athens is a wonderful place to live and quite inexpensive.
cons: Unfortunately, the university divests a great amount of resources in athletic programs, in detriment of other areas which should be more central to an institution of higher education, such as library resources.

review_title: Overall a great job for students in college to get some extra spending money.
pros: They are very flexible with students on hours. They dont give out too much work, and the work is pretty trivial. A lot of time to study or do homework if need be.
cons: Can find yourself at work doing nothing. Sometimes they make you do work that you feel is not in your job description (like sweep or get someone a drink from the vending machine)

review_title: Tutor at the Rankin Academic Center, supporting student athletes academically to help them in pursuit of their academic
pros: Get to work with students and help them succeed, staff are great people and helpful when you need them
cons: Scheduling issues, frequently a student-athlete would be a no show (you get paid for half an hour), or they cancel and you don't receive appropriate notice

review_title: Great environment, but don't expect raises
job_title: Research Professional I in Athens, GA
pros: Great environment to work in. Employee moral seems high. Football season is fun, but can be disruptive to laboratory work, since you cannot easily access campus. Athens is an enjoyable, diverse town with a lot to offer.
cons: Budget cuts and concerns caused a lack of raises for several years. The current pay scale is behind the times. A large pool of recent graduates flood the market for entry level jobs, making them difficult to attain.

review_title: Super chill not a lot of pay
job_title: Facility Operations Staff in Athens, GA
pros:
Relaxed Workspace
Great way to meet other students
Room for promotion
cons:
Can be in-group : out-group, If you aren't in the in-group then it can be hard to get promoted.
It was hard to get rid of shifts and the higherups wouldn't help you too much in this aspect.
Hiring comittee members aren't always suited for the job
Low pay

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Athens, GA
pros: UGA has a very strong reputation academically. The students are top notch, and the local college town is a great environment for students, families, and academics alike. The bus system here is incredibly efficient and convenient.
cons: Parking on campus can be an issue at times.
